title: Paula Dwyer safe despite big Tabcorp protest vote
text:
Gaming and wagering group Tabcorp chairman Paula Dwyer received a 34.7 per cent vote against her re-election, amid discontent among investors that the group isn't delivering the benefits from its Tattersalls merger fast enough.

While there were sizeable protest votes against most resolutions around remuneration and director re-election, Tabcorp headed off the prospect of a board spill which would have been required had votes cast for the remuneration report fallen short of 75 per cent.

About 85 per cent of proxies were cast in favour of the remuneration report, with 14.46 per cent of proxy votes cast against it. Tabcorp last year received a first strike (40.4 per cent) against its remuneration report at last year’s AGM in Brisbane.

Chairman Paula Dwyer said Tabcorp will use its voice on animal welfare. Wayne Taylor

Ms Dwyer, who has been on the board since 2005, was re-elected with 64.58 per cent of proxy votes cast in her favour. Justin Milne, who was also up for re-election, received 20.17 per cent of proxy votes against it, but was re-elected with 79.18 per cent of proxy votes cast in his favour.

Some 62.69 per cent of proxies were cast in favour of granting performance shares to chief executive David Attenborough, with proxies against 36.69 per cent.
description: Tabcorp chairman Paula Dwyer faced a protest vote at the company's annual meeting.
